NEW YORK — The so-called most fabulous super-villain on the Internet has experienced an extremely turbulent 90 hours. 
Minutes before a Tuesday afternoon press conference in Lower Manhattan, the news broke that Milo Yiannopoulos, a British conservative polemicist, just resigned from his technology editor position at Breitbart News. 
That newsflash arrived on the heels of Simon & Schuster's cancellation of Yiannopoulos' much-anticipated memoir Dangerous , which had been slated for a March 14 release. Milo Yiannopoulos holds a press conference in New York on February 21. The conservative firebrand Milo Yiannopoulos resigned from the news site Breitbart amid a storm triggered by comments in which he seems to condone pedophilia. (AFP PHOTO / TIMOTHY A. CLARYTIMOTHY A. CLARY/AFP/Getty Images) 
Even with at least 20 news cameras pointed at his podium, it seemed Yiannopoulos' options as a media figure were quickly running out. 
With the solemnity of a White House press secretary announcing a national tragedy, Yiannopoulos began reading from a prepared statement. 
"I am a gay man and a child abuse victim. Between the ages of 13 and 16, two men touched me in ways they should not have. One of those men was a priest," he said. 
For this occasion, Yiannopoulos' formality was appropriate. 
Over the weekend, two freewheeling video interviews — one from 2015 with comedian Joe Rogan; the other dating back to at least July 2016 — regained traction on the internet. 
Yiannopoulos had recounted being an underage victim at the hands of adult sexual offenders. But while dissecting pedophilia during those interviews, Yiannopoulos neglected to flat-out condemn his abusers, which swiftly inspired the loss of the book contract. 
That same day, the 2017 Conservative Political Action Conference disinvited Yiannopoulos as its keynote speaker. 
However, during Tuesday's press conference, Yiannopoulos announced that other publishers have already expressed interest in finding a home for his Dangerous book. 
But things had dramatically shifted since the previous Friday evening, when Yiannopoulos appeared on the HBO talk show Real Time with Bill Maher . 
On Tuesday, Yiannopoulos was decked out in a blue suit with a red tie. To sit across from Maher, he chose a pearlescent necklace with a matching bracelet. 
During the Tuesday press conference, Yiannopoulos apologized. And for a verbal provocateur and self-identified free-speech advocate who's been permanently banned from Twitter, that clarification is actually newsworthy. 
"I am certainly guilty of imprecise language, which I regret," he said. "But for those statements I did make where I misspoke, I do apologize. 
"I've never apologized for anything else before. I don't anticipate doing it again. But this particular subject strikes pretty close to home," he continued. 
While the press conference was held on the 11th floor of an office building, the chants of anti-Yiannopoulos protesters from the sidewalk below could be heard as he took questions from reporters. 
"The book will come out this year as planned — with perhaps an additional chapter. I'll be donating 10 percent of my royalties to child sex abuse charities," Yiannopoulos said. 
The decision to drop Dangerous comes at a high price. According to The New York Times , Yiannopoulos received a $250,000 advance . 
His literary agent, Thomas Flannery Jr., says the title was nearing 50,000 copies in advance sales. 
Editor's note : Daniel Kusner is a freelance writer based in Dallas and New York View Comments
